FitzGerald pledges to address problem of absenteeism at meetings
by Tom McNamara
"I want to get away from politics this
year and concentrate more on why we're
here and on doing things for the
students,'said Student Council President
Scott FitzGerald at the first Council
meeting of the year, held Wednesday.
Discussion at what FitzGerald called
"an organizational meeting" suggested
that academic issues will be an important
concern of the Council this year.
In addition, FitzGerald.stressed that the
purpose of the Council is to solve problems
that individual students are not able to handle. He enjoined members to be receptive
to concerns of this nature when their constituents express them.
FitzGerald and others said that academic
questions were an important part of discussion at the Woods Retreat, a conference
held among students and members of the
faculty and administration.
Housing Committee Chairwoman Lora
Sims said that discussion on the possible
** * * * *

institution of an honor code at Hopkins
focused on the fact that "there is an ethics
crisis on campus right now." She said that
a significant number of students cheat in
at least some classes, and specifically mentioned falsification of data in laboratory
courses.
According to Sims,discussions of possible causes led to general agreement that
they may include strong competition between students and the use of grading
"curves," which produces grades depending at least in part upon comparisons between students rather than on some absolute
standard of performance.
Sims said that since one goal of the
University is to produce their own
research, which must be either honest or
worthless, "ultimately there must be an
honor code."
FitzGerald also addressed the question
of absenteeism, which occasionally hobbled last year's Student Council when votes
on vital issues could not be held because
of lack of a quorum.

He said that "universities like
to have five year plans in

have the strongest undergraduate
program we can produce."
He spoke also of the need to attract and retain high quality faculty. "There will be, nationally, a
very large number of faculty
retirements, and these are, in
general, the most senior and distinguished people. The competition for replacing them with high
quality faculty is going to be
fierce, and there's not as many
quality young people out there."
He concluded, "You want to
be able to go after them aggressively, and you can't do that
without a plan."

at the Joint Institute for

the National Science Foundation.

the American Physical Society,
where he serves on the Panel of

McKhann fills top post at Mind-Brain Institute
by Weifen Chang
In July, the two top posts at the University's new Mind-Brain Institute were filled.
Guy Mead McKhann, director of the
Department of Neurology at the Hopkins
School of Medicine, was named director
of the institute, and Ruth Leys, former
dean for program development in the
School of Arts and Sciences, was appointed executive director.
Established in May, the Mind-Brain Institute will bring together the resources of
the fields of neuroscience and the more
abstract cognitive sciences to try to answer
questions concerning both the "mind" and

the "brain" — questions about memory,
language, perception, and other subjects.
The institute will be one of several
similar programs across the country, including those at the University of Southern
California, the Massachusetts Institute of
Technology, and the University of Illinois
at Urbana-Campaign.
According to University President
Steven Muller, McKhann, with Leys's
assistance, will be responsible for recruitment of senior research scientists, the
selection of an appropriate site for the Institute on the Homewood campus, the

A Little Lee Way
by A. Lee Davis

Facing Change
The opportunity for change presents
itself in all kinds of ways. This summer,
two men took the helm of the School of
Arts and Sciences. The School's newly
appointed dean, Dr. Lloyd Armstrong,
brings expertise from his former position as chairman of the Department of
Physics and Astronomy; the new
associate dean, Dr. P. Kyle McCarter,
professor in the Near Eastern Studies
Department, complements Armstrong
with his humanities background.
Armstrong and McCarter, in taking
these positions, assume responsibility
for the academic climate at Homewood.
Their experience, as well as the experience of their predecessors, can and
should be implemented as they try to
ascertain the status of education in the
School of Arts and Sciences. However,
Armstrong and McCarter's experience
comes from two faculty members'
perspectives. As they assume their new
positions, they will need to understand
the concerns of all members of the
Hopkins community.. Armstrong and
McCarter might most effectively fill
their roles if they take what they have
gained here, organize it and hold it as
if under one arm, and keep the other
hand free to shake and greet new ideas
and challenges within the community.

This fall Hopkins will see yet another
new face— the Mind-Brain Institute.
While this new program might seemingly be of little concern for Homewood
undergraduates, it could in the future be
instrumental in helping alter the purposes and goals of the University.
Established as an attempt to bring
together the fields of neuroscience with
the cognitive sciences, the Institute will
house the laboratories and offices of top
researchers in fields such as
neurobiology and psychology. They
will work together, investigating areas
such as memory, perception, movement
control, and language.
With the ever-increasing accumulation of all kinds of knowledge, scien-

tists become more and more deeply entrenched in specialties of their field. It
is easy to lose sight of the ultimate purpose of scientific study: a continual attempt to improve, in all ways, the quality of life. The inter-departmental focus
of the Mind-Brain Institute will force
researchers to step back from their own
projects and study the ways in which information gathered from other fields can
aid their own work.
Perhaps the Institute can lend itself—
at least in principle— to the curricula for
the Schools of Arts and Sciences and
Engineering. The inter-departmental approach obviously contributes greatly to
the understanding of a given topic. It
also serves as a vehicle by which a more
well-rounded education is achieved.
This approach would certainly
necessitate a change in attitudes towards
academics here, since many Hopkins
students tend to follow a preprofessional course of studies; such curricula are intense and very competitive
and leave little time for appreciation of
other fields. The implementation of this
type of change is made more complex
by the Hopkins legacy of graduate
study. Historically, Hopkins was established as a research university in the
likeness of the great European schools.
Taking into consideration our history,
the shift towards a varied curriculum is
that much more fundamental. Homewood Administrators, new and old,
should consider the benefits of such
changes without being reticent because
of its deviance from current attitudes.
On the contrary, they should feel comfortable that the two approaches are
compatible. For example, the University's strengths in independent study
programs can lend itself just as easily
to inter-departmental research.
Both the appointments in the School
of Arts and Sciences and the establishment of the Mind-Brain Institute present
the potential for change, directly and indirectly, for the undergraduates at
Homewood. This potential should be
realized.

Summer movie wrap-up
by Loren Fox and Frank Wu
A good many terrible films
have come out this summer, but
there have been some worthwhile
movies that are still playing in the
area. Below are nine films many
students will consider seeing in
their brief respites from studying.
Choose carefully. For movie
times, call the theatres: Movies at
Harborpark, 837-3500; The
Rotunda, 235-1800; Towson Art
Cinema, 823-2436.
The Big Easy is a romantic
police story. Dennis Quaid is one
of the best New Orleans cops,
believing that he is one of the last
good guys—fighting the Mafia
("Wise guys" in this town).
Ellen Barkin, a district attorney's
investigator, thinks that the petty
corruption of the police force has
gone too far. They puzzle over a
gang war, they fall in love.
Quaid, with his thick-tongued
rendition of an New Orleans accent, is far too cutesy for his own
good, but he and Barkin have one
of the best romance scenes of recent movies. The Big Easy,
however, is too easy about relations between races, sexes, and
power and responsibility. This is
a decent movie; it is also one that
will lull the audience into accepting the contrived for the real.
Rotunda. B-.
The Fourth Protocol is an espionage thriller based on
Frederick Forsyth's book of that
title. It stars Michael Caine as a
British counter-intelligence agent
with more humor than reserve,
and Pierce "almost-James-Bond"
Brosnan as a top Soviet agent
assigned to build and detonate an
atomic bomb by a U.S. airbase.

Forsyth's plot has been streamlined, but because the movie uses
the same fast pacing and short
episodes, it may be difficult to
follow. Caine shows that his omnipresence is not all bad; his
character and those of the other
British agents are all fine.
Brosnan is adequate (his role is
too cool and flat). The other
Soviets are laughable: a KGB
general Ned Beatty is not. Less
than thrilling. Rotunda. B-.
The Living Daylights is the new
James Bond movie, starring the
newest James Bond, Timothy
Dalton. Dalton brings good
dramatic acting to the role, but
fails to convey the sense of fun
that Connery or even Moore did.
This James Bond is tense and.
tired. The plot is silly, as usual,
centering on covert arms deals.
For some reason a KGB general
must be killed, but it's all very
muddled. There are some neat
stunts, including a cello snow
chase (say that three times fast).
Bond's love interest, Maryam
D'Abo, is sexy but lacks the
glamour of, say, Fawn Hall. The
umpteenth outing of007 is disappointing, although the vehicle
wore thin ten years ago. For
Bond fanatics only. Harbor. B-.
La Bamba follows the rise and
death of Ritchie Valens, the 17
year old rock star killed in the
same plane crash as Buddy Holly and the Big Bopper(remember
"American Pie"?). This is not a
showbiz story; this is a story
about a Hispanic teenager who
lives the American Dream. Lou
Diamond Philips makes a good
Valens, and Los Lobos sing the
songs with gusto. Ritchie isn't
nearly as interesting as his "bad"
brother, and the occasional des-

cent into soap opera doesn't help.
But this is a good, honest film.
and an adult film you can take the
kids to see. Director Luis Valdez
handles the concert scenes well.
Marshall Crenshaw makes a
wonderful cameo as Buddy Holly. Towson. B+.
No Way Out presents Kevin
Costner in his second major role
of the summer. He is a naval hero
who gets transferred to the Pentagon. Gene Hackman is the
Secretary of Defense and Sean
Young his mistress. Party girl
Young falls for upwardly mobile
Costner. Hackman ckiesn't know
who Young is seeing, but he is
very jealous—he "accidentally"
kills her. The cover-up begins.
Hackman and his aide (Will Patton) decide the "other man" will
be blamed. The catch is, they
assign that mission to that very
man, Costner. Costner is hardly
lackluster in this desperate role,
but he has not shown versatility
in his work this summer.
Hackman and Patton give better
performances, as weak men given
power. The ending does not ruin
the movie: it is the camp version
of elegant, geometrical storytelling. Rotunda. B +.
Robocop will fool you. Most
people will think it's a typical
Schwarzenegger-Stallone kill the
world flick. It's actually intelligent, well-handled science
fiction. Robocop is part of the
movement called "Cyberpunk"
which, like Max Headroom,
believes that the near future will
be a dismal landscape of urban
decay and bureaucratic masturbation. Director Paul Verhoeven
has made a comic-book on the big
screen, and filled it with several
levels of meaning and satire.

Sean Young and Kevin Costner in No Way Out.
Peter Weller (Buckaroo Banzai,,
plays the mechanized copper
well, although he got the role
because as a long-distance runner, he was the only one who
could act under 200 lbs. of
makeup. Give the man a hand. If
a little violence doesn't scare you
off, go see this cross between
Repo Man and A Boy and Has
Dog. Bring your sense of irony.
Harbor. A-.
Roxanne is Steve Martin's clever
modernization of the Cyrano
story. Martin is the fire chief in
a small western town with a really, really big schnozz. He falls
for visiting astronomer Daryl
Hannah. What follows is one of
the brightest, crispest movies of
the year. Forget that it pales in
comparison to Rostand's brilliant
play. There is no "Thus as I end
the refrain" scene; instead, Steve
Martin beats up two guys with a
tennis racket. This is Steve Martin at his best, unusually intelligent, funny, athletic and
sharp. This is a film for people
who promise not to compare it to
the play. Towson. A-.
Stakeout is an easy movie to like.
Richard Dreyfuss and Emilio
Estevez are Seattle cops watching
the ex-girlfriend of a recently
escaped convict; Dreyfuss falls
for the woman (Madeleine Stowe)
and life becomes hectic for all in-

volved. Dreyfuss confirms his
return from oblivion and Estevez
shows he is an adult at last. Stowe
is sweet in her role, in a summer
bearing too few strong women's
roles. There is no excuse for the
relish with which director John
Badham (Blue Thunder)turns out
the typical car chase and dream
sequence. Although the movie is
juvenile, with no pretensions, it
is also enjoyable. Harbor. B.
The Untouchables confirms
what we've long suspected: Brian
De Palma is an excellent stylist
who longs desperately to be an
auteur but unfortunately has
nothing to say. In this confrontation between Al Capone (Robert
DeNiro) and Elliot Ness (Kevin
Costner), De Palma avoids Hitchcock and steals instead from
Eisenstein and Woody Allen.
Costner has been touted as
Hollywood's new leading man,
but judging from his Ness.
Hollywood must be looking for a
bland mix of Mark Harmon and
Tom Cruise. DeNiro plays
Capone as an opera character.
and we never get to see him alone
or personal. Actually, it's the best
looking movie of the summer,
although there was no reason to
make it. Sean Connery steals the
show as a walking cliche. Harbor. B.

anything that moves faster than

you do. Next, never eat anything

your head. The last is don't eat
anything that can be used as a
glue substitute (but they do agree
that these things can be useful in
putting up more shelf space in the
dorm rooms). Using your common sense and remembering that

Angeles." As the novel takes the
reader through an utterly burntout reality, this statement
presumably takes on much
greater significance.
The major episodes of Clay's
vacation involve some friends
who have been keeping a twelve
year-old girl for their amusement;
homosexual prostitution; and finding a dead body. Clay is cool,
hardly caring about any of this,
but on a visit to his psychiatrist,
"coming off from coke, sneezing
blood," the doctor asks him
about Elvis Costello and he asks
back,"'what about me?'"
"'What about you?"
"What about me?"
— You'll be fine."
"I don't know,' I say. 'I don't
think so."
— Let's talk about something
else."
"What about me?' I scream,
choking."
"Come on, Clay. . . Don't be
so mundane."
Later Clay, disinterested more
than anything else, asks his friend
who has the captive twelve yearold, —Oh shit . . . what don't you
have?"
don't have anything to
lose."
And the reader has little to lose
or gain from this sordid story.
Although Ellis does display a
mastery of his chosen venue, his
tone is neutral and so ends up exalting in the situation it presents,
rather than offering any comment. There is certainly not
enough humanity for the upcoming movie version to present Clay
as somewhat of a moral fellow
trying to rescue his friends from
their own angst, as has been
reported. That would require an
incredible talent for revision, or
great tolerance for the Clay's
brand of sickly melancholy,
which he believes to be strong,
mature emotion. The bands,
clothes, MTV and videogames

are out already and the story is
dated, so what is offered by Less
Than Zero? One of the best
documents of the era. Stripped of
the hype, taken as a first novel instead of a masterpiece, set into
perspective, yes, the work has a
certain on-the-edge quality as a
report on our own frightening
culture and as a demonstration of
taut writing rather than as serious
literature.
From the slight historical vantage that is now available, the
question that the novel presents is
whether or not Ellis can carry his
work by slick writing alone. After
all, hipster doomsday sentimentality wears well only for those
who die young.
Unfortunately, with his second
book, Rules of Attraction, Ellis
shows that he prefers working in
a disPollyanna vacuum. The new
novel is one of the worst works
of fiction ever published.
It tells of a group of apathetic
students at Camden, the small
liberal arts college in New
England, Less Than Zero Clay's
school. Clay doesn't appear until late in the book, but among his
peers, there is Lauren, who can't
get over her ex-boyfriend Victor,
and who is distinguished (barely)
by her changing majors all of the
time. The dustjacket praises Paul
as a bisexual "whose passion
masks a shrewd pragmatism," as
is demonstrated by his reaction to
a someone bursting into his room
before a big date with news of a
suicide attempt: "He looked like
he was going to cry and he gave
this event (a Freshman suicide?
oh, please) a dimension of unwarranted emotion." Sean, with
whom Paul sleeps, because he
owns a motorcycle, is the central
characater. His attitude sums up
the novel: "Yeah. I'm going to
the party tonight. You going .0
the
tonight?"'.

After discovering success with his first novel, Less Than Zero, Bret Easton
Ellis continues his streak in The Rules ofAttraction.
episodes, switching points of
view to no great effect, making
it only more difficult to iort out
the empty affairs and petty concerns of each character. The
chore is hardly worth the effort,
especially since Ellis repeats
scenes with the same may-aswell-be-dead tone.
Were the novel to be redeemed by anything, it would be witticisms, trademark minimalist
sarcasm. The trouble is that, in
this novel, what are intende,i as
pointed observations are talc tall
too seriously by the characters
and the author, as they wonder
who the secret admirer is and
what will happen at The Dressed
To Get Screwed party (there is no
further plot). Clay, for example,
recasts his opening line from the
last novel, concluding that people
are afraid to merge on campus.
Victor: "I didn't know where I
was. Everything was full of
tourists. So I went to this nude
beach. Hung out, got naked, ate
yogurt and swam with these two
Yugoslavian guys who complained about inflation and wanted to
make me a Socialist."
Sean: "Like all rich hippies. . . she spent a lot of time
following The Dead around.
She'd simply split school for a
week with other rich hippies and
they'd follow them around New
England, stoned out of their
minds, reserving rooms and
suites at Holiday Inns and
Howard Johnsons and Ramada
Inns, making sure to always have
enough Blue Dragon or MDA or
MDMA or Ecstasy. She'd come
back from these excursions
ecstatic, claiming that. . .she was
truly one of 'Jerry's kids.' I guess
she was one of Jerry's kids,
though I wasn't sure which
kind."
The Secret Admirer: "Mouthbreathing waitresses came on to
You, You, who were bronzed
like a God, a GQ man, Your hair
slicked back."
Lauren: "What else is one .to
do at college except drink beer or

slash your wrists?"
Ellis has re-found the lost
generation, but fails to notice that
they have lost themselves. It
represents no particular moral
stand to criticize this, for the
characters are amoral, without
even an articulate amorality. So
engrossed in fast living are the
college students that inhabit
Ellisland, they would be unlikely to read even Less Than Zero,
or Rules of Attraction. Yuppies
at least work. The Ellis children
lead lives that are a blur; their
story is worthless. The style does
not even hold the seamless quality that was so admired in the first
novel.
The greater crime here is not
that Ellis espouses some sort of
heinous lifestyle (which he does,
by most standards), but that he
does a lousy job of telling a story.
His characters don't care. Why
should the reader?
Ellis perhaps realizes what he
is doing: Sean and Lauren attend
a party at her poetry teacher's
house, where they meet Stump
("Used to be Carcass but changed it"), and have an interesting
discussion on writing. Stump is a
poet who has learned his art from
Black Flag and he is writing a
series about bestiality. "I'm
working on the dog section now
where this guy ties a dog up and
is having intercourse with it
because He thinks dog is God. D.G-0-D. God spelled
O-G
backwards. Get it? See?"
Another artist asks whether this
"post-Vietman, post-Watergate,
post- . . . hell, post-everything"
writing is worthwhile, or just
"bogus."
Were Ellis to apply his not inconsiderable stylistic skill to a
worthwhile story, he would begin
to live up to the gushing he has
inspired. Rules of Attraction,
however, is deserving of not even
faint and fading praise.

as so many Americans seem to be

doing. There will be 2000 deaths

for cases in which overexposure

tissue damage, or caused irretrievable loss of eye or brain
function.

**I()apply sunscreen when you expect

College-age men and women
to be the worst abusers of

to Florida and often participating
in campus tanning as well.
Hopkins, with its studious image,
is not immune from the call of the
rays either. The "Beach — in front
of MSE has had over 100 people

Suntanning is, medically speaking, an absorption of ultraviolet
rays from sunlight or artificially
induced light that causes the skin
cells in our bodies to produce
melanin, a dark pigment which
causes our skin to tan. Too much
of that sun will dehydratt- the skin
and kill the cells in the skin's
outer layer.
We are all exposed to the sun
to some extent. and a fair amount
of sunlight is undoubtedly
healthy, contributing items such
as vitamin D for our body's use.
The concern, however, is that
people generally do not know
their limits and overexpose
themselves. That doesn't just
mean burning, however. Even if
you never burn, you may be
receiving too much ultraviolet
radiation and so may suffer later
from some of the diseases
associated with too much radiation, cancers being the most
serious.
There is no. cause for alarm,
sun-seekers, but there is a list of
precautions which dermatologists
and the Skin Cancer Foundation
recommend following
to
minimize your risk (see box).

reasonable adherence to these
seem-

measures will ensure healthy skin

the dreaded diseases and
premature wrinkling that have
been seen in increasing numbers.

overlooked these safe and simple
rules, unfortunately, and dermatologists have seen the average

Reagan is an example of a
Southern Californian with skin
cancer problems, but many doctors have claimed that some
Californians have had to deal with
the skin-salvaging procedures
such as surgery at half the President's age.

use of tanning salons. Nationally

Patrick and Benjamin Binder,
a pair of West German Siamese
twins that came to Hopkins
Hospital this month in order to be
separated are recuperating well,
according to spokespersons at the
Hospital. The twins, connected at
the back of their heads, were
separated in a grueling 22-hour
operation on September 5 and 6.
A team of over 70 physicians,
nurses, and health care personnel
attended the operation.
The twins are in a "critical but
stable condition" as this paper
goes to press. .Hospital
spokespersons report that the
twins are being slowly weaned
from their drug-induced coma.
Doctors have kept the twins in an
artificial state of coma with barbituates since the operation last
week in order to promote healing.
The prognosis for the 7 month
old twins seems good—breathing_

has returned to normal and their
arms and legs seem to be functioning well. The twins were
placed on their stomachs early
this week in order to allow the
wounds in their heads to heal
quickly. "It's the first time the
twins have probably been lying
on their stomachs ever," the
Hospital has noted.
The Binder operation was a
unique opportunity for the
Hopkins staff, the first Siamese
separation the Hospital has performed in five years. Doctors used hypothermia and a heart/lung
bypass machine in order to drain
the blood vessels and inactivate
the heart and circulatory systems
for about an hour. This allowed
physicians to separate the major
sinus vein (located near the brain)
that the twins shared. The vein
was separated without incident
and new vessels were constructed
for each twin from tissue from
their hearts. The twins had fully
separated and normally functioning brains.
The twins were in the operating

room last Friday again, but this
time fOr a routine cleansing of
their wounds in order to prevent
the risk of infection. The twohour operation performed on each
twin was primarily so surgeons
could — irrigate and cleanse their
wounds," a routine precautionary
measure for major post-operative
procedure. The twins were
reported to have responded well
to the additional surgery.
The next step for the twins is
to place permanent customdesigned titanium-mesh caps over
the openings doctors have cut in
the infants' skulls. The procedure
has been delayed so far because
Benjamin has been having a little
problem with brain swelling and
the doctors want to allow him
some more convalescent time.
Pediatricians at the Hospital
believe the Binder twins will
grow up to be normal, healthy
adults, but it is still early ib the
game and no one can know for
sure. Doctors will be able to give
a more informed opinion several
months from now.

A Little Lee Way
by A. Lee Davis

Facing Change
The opportunity for change presents
itself in all kinds of ways. This summer,
two men took the helm of the School of
Arts and Sciences. The School's newly
appointed dean, Dr. Lloyd Armstrong,
brings expertise from his former position as chairman of the Department of
Physics and Astronomy; the new
associate dean, Dr. P. Kyle McCarter,
professor in the Near Eastern Studies
Department, complements Armstrong
with his humanities background.
Armstrong and McCarter, in taking
these positions, assume responsibility
for the academic climate at Homewood.
Their experience, as well as the experience of their predecessors, can and
should be implemented as they try to
ascertain the status of education in the
School of Arts and Sciences. However,
Armstrong and McCarter's experience
comes from two faculty members'
perspectives. As they assume their new
positions, they will need to understand
the concerns of all members of the
Hopkins community.. Armstrong and
McCarter might most effectively fill
their roles if they take what they have
gained here, organize it and hold it as
if under one arm, and keep the other
hand free to shake and greet new ideas
and challenges within the community.

This fall Hopkins will see yet another
new face— the Mind-Brain Institute.
While this new program might seemingly be of little concern for Homewood
undergraduates, it could in the future be
instrumental in helping alter the purposes and goals of the University.
Established as an attempt to bring
together the fields of neuroscience with
the cognitive sciences, the Institute will
house the laboratories and offices of top
researchers in fields such as
neurobiology and psychology. They
will work together, investigating areas
such as memory, perception, movement
control, and language.
With the ever-increasing accumulation of all kinds of knowledge, scien-

tists become more and more deeply entrenched in specialties of their field. It
is easy to lose sight of the ultimate purpose of scientific study: a continual attempt to improve, in all ways, the quality of life. The inter-departmental focus
of the Mind-Brain Institute will force
researchers to step back from their own
projects and study the ways in which information gathered from other fields can
aid their own work.
Perhaps the Institute can lend itself—
at least in principle— to the curricula for
the Schools of Arts and Sciences and
Engineering. The inter-departmental approach obviously contributes greatly to
the understanding of a given topic. It
also serves as a vehicle by which a more
well-rounded education is achieved.
This approach would certainly
necessitate a change in attitudes towards
academics here, since many Hopkins
students tend to follow a preprofessional course of studies; such curricula are intense and very competitive
and leave little time for appreciation of
other fields. The implementation of this
type of change is made more complex
by the Hopkins legacy of graduate
study. Historically, Hopkins was established as a research university in the
likeness of the great European schools.
Taking into consideration our history,
the shift towards a varied curriculum is
that much more fundamental. Homewood Administrators, new and old,
should consider the benefits of such
changes without being reticent because
of its deviance from current attitudes.
On the contrary, they should feel comfortable that the two approaches are
compatible. For example, the University's strengths in independent study
programs can lend itself just as easily
to inter-departmental research.
Both the appointments in the School
of Arts and Sciences and the establishment of the Mind-Brain Institute present
the potential for change, directly and indirectly, for the undergraduates at
Homewood. This potential should be
realized.

Summer movie wrap-up
by Loren Fox and Frank Wu
A good many terrible films
have come out this summer, but
there have been some worthwhile
movies that are still playing in the
area. Below are nine films many
students will consider seeing in
their brief respites from studying.
Choose carefully. For movie
times, call the theatres: Movies at
Harborpark, 837-3500; The
Rotunda, 235-1800; Towson Art
Cinema, 823-2436.
The Big Easy is a romantic
police story. Dennis Quaid is one
of the best New Orleans cops,
believing that he is one of the last
good guys—fighting the Mafia
("Wise guys" in this town).
Ellen Barkin, a district attorney's
investigator, thinks that the petty
corruption of the police force has
gone too far. They puzzle over a
gang war, they fall in love.
Quaid, with his thick-tongued
rendition of an New Orleans accent, is far too cutesy for his own
good, but he and Barkin have one
of the best romance scenes of recent movies. The Big Easy,
however, is too easy about relations between races, sexes, and
power and responsibility. This is
a decent movie; it is also one that
will lull the audience into accepting the contrived for the real.
Rotunda. B-.
The Fourth Protocol is an espionage thriller based on
Frederick Forsyth's book of that
title. It stars Michael Caine as a
British counter-intelligence agent
with more humor than reserve,
and Pierce "almost-James-Bond"
Brosnan as a top Soviet agent
assigned to build and detonate an
atomic bomb by a U.S. airbase.

Forsyth's plot has been streamlined, but because the movie uses
the same fast pacing and short
episodes, it may be difficult to
follow. Caine shows that his omnipresence is not all bad; his
character and those of the other
British agents are all fine.
Brosnan is adequate (his role is
too cool and flat). The other
Soviets are laughable: a KGB
general Ned Beatty is not. Less
than thrilling. Rotunda. B-.
The Living Daylights is the new
James Bond movie, starring the
newest James Bond, Timothy
Dalton. Dalton brings good
dramatic acting to the role, but
fails to convey the sense of fun
that Connery or even Moore did.
This James Bond is tense and.
tired. The plot is silly, as usual,
centering on covert arms deals.
For some reason a KGB general
must be killed, but it's all very
muddled. There are some neat
stunts, including a cello snow
chase (say that three times fast).
Bond's love interest, Maryam
D'Abo, is sexy but lacks the
glamour of, say, Fawn Hall. The
umpteenth outing of007 is disappointing, although the vehicle
wore thin ten years ago. For
Bond fanatics only. Harbor. B-.
La Bamba follows the rise and
death of Ritchie Valens, the 17
year old rock star killed in the
same plane crash as Buddy Holly and the Big Bopper(remember
"American Pie"?). This is not a
showbiz story; this is a story
about a Hispanic teenager who
lives the American Dream. Lou
Diamond Philips makes a good
Valens, and Los Lobos sing the
songs with gusto. Ritchie isn't
nearly as interesting as his "bad"
brother, and the occasional des-

cent into soap opera doesn't help.
But this is a good, honest film.
and an adult film you can take the
kids to see. Director Luis Valdez
handles the concert scenes well.
Marshall Crenshaw makes a
wonderful cameo as Buddy Holly. Towson. B+.
No Way Out presents Kevin
Costner in his second major role
of the summer. He is a naval hero
who gets transferred to the Pentagon. Gene Hackman is the
Secretary of Defense and Sean
Young his mistress. Party girl
Young falls for upwardly mobile
Costner. Hackman ckiesn't know
who Young is seeing, but he is
very jealous—he "accidentally"
kills her. The cover-up begins.
Hackman and his aide (Will Patton) decide the "other man" will
be blamed. The catch is, they
assign that mission to that very
man, Costner. Costner is hardly
lackluster in this desperate role,
but he has not shown versatility
in his work this summer.
Hackman and Patton give better
performances, as weak men given
power. The ending does not ruin
the movie: it is the camp version
of elegant, geometrical storytelling. Rotunda. B +.
Robocop will fool you. Most
people will think it's a typical
Schwarzenegger-Stallone kill the
world flick. It's actually intelligent, well-handled science
fiction. Robocop is part of the
movement called "Cyberpunk"
which, like Max Headroom,
believes that the near future will
be a dismal landscape of urban
decay and bureaucratic masturbation. Director Paul Verhoeven
has made a comic-book on the big
screen, and filled it with several
levels of meaning and satire.

Sean Young and Kevin Costner in No Way Out.
Peter Weller (Buckaroo Banzai,,
plays the mechanized copper
well, although he got the role
because as a long-distance runner, he was the only one who
could act under 200 lbs. of
makeup. Give the man a hand. If
a little violence doesn't scare you
off, go see this cross between
Repo Man and A Boy and Has
Dog. Bring your sense of irony.
Harbor. A-.
Roxanne is Steve Martin's clever
modernization of the Cyrano
story. Martin is the fire chief in
a small western town with a really, really big schnozz. He falls
for visiting astronomer Daryl
Hannah. What follows is one of
the brightest, crispest movies of
the year. Forget that it pales in
comparison to Rostand's brilliant
play. There is no "Thus as I end
the refrain" scene; instead, Steve
Martin beats up two guys with a
tennis racket. This is Steve Martin at his best, unusually intelligent, funny, athletic and
sharp. This is a film for people
who promise not to compare it to
the play. Towson. A-.
Stakeout is an easy movie to like.
Richard Dreyfuss and Emilio
Estevez are Seattle cops watching
the ex-girlfriend of a recently
escaped convict; Dreyfuss falls
for the woman (Madeleine Stowe)
and life becomes hectic for all in-

volved. Dreyfuss confirms his
return from oblivion and Estevez
shows he is an adult at last. Stowe
is sweet in her role, in a summer
bearing too few strong women's
roles. There is no excuse for the
relish with which director John
Badham (Blue Thunder)turns out
the typical car chase and dream
sequence. Although the movie is
juvenile, with no pretensions, it
is also enjoyable. Harbor. B.
The Untouchables confirms
what we've long suspected: Brian
De Palma is an excellent stylist
who longs desperately to be an
auteur but unfortunately has
nothing to say. In this confrontation between Al Capone (Robert
DeNiro) and Elliot Ness (Kevin
Costner), De Palma avoids Hitchcock and steals instead from
Eisenstein and Woody Allen.
Costner has been touted as
Hollywood's new leading man,
but judging from his Ness.
Hollywood must be looking for a
bland mix of Mark Harmon and
Tom Cruise. DeNiro plays
Capone as an opera character.
and we never get to see him alone
or personal. Actually, it's the best
looking movie of the summer,
although there was no reason to
make it. Sean Connery steals the
show as a walking cliche. Harbor. B.

sarcasm. The trouble is that, in
this novel, what are intende,i as
pointed observations are talc tall
too seriously by the characters
and the author, as they wonder
who the secret admirer is and
what will happen at The Dressed
To Get Screwed party (there is no
further plot). Clay, for example,
recasts his opening line from the
last novel, concluding that people
are afraid to merge on campus.
Victor: "I didn't know where I
was. Everything was full of
tourists. So I went to this nude
beach. Hung out, got naked, ate
yogurt and swam with these two
Yugoslavian guys who complained about inflation and wanted to
make me a Socialist."
Sean: "Like all rich hippies. . . she spent a lot of time
following The Dead around.
She'd simply split school for a
week with other rich hippies and
they'd follow them around New
England, stoned out of their
minds, reserving rooms and
suites at Holiday Inns and
Howard Johnsons and Ramada
Inns, making sure to always have
enough Blue Dragon or MDA or
MDMA or Ecstasy. She'd come
back from these excursions
ecstatic, claiming that. . .she was
truly one of 'Jerry's kids.' I guess
she was one of Jerry's kids,
though I wasn't sure which
kind."
The Secret Admirer: "Mouthbreathing waitresses came on to
You, You, who were bronzed
like a God, a GQ man, Your hair
slicked back."
Lauren: "What else is one .to
do at college except drink beer or

slash your wrists?"
Ellis has re-found the lost
generation, but fails to notice that
they have lost themselves. It
represents no particular moral
stand to criticize this, for the
characters are amoral, without
even an articulate amorality. So
engrossed in fast living are the
college students that inhabit
Ellisland, they would be unlikely to read even Less Than Zero,
or Rules of Attraction. Yuppies
at least work. The Ellis children
lead lives that are a blur; their
story is worthless. The style does
not even hold the seamless quality that was so admired in the first
novel.
The greater crime here is not
that Ellis espouses some sort of
heinous lifestyle (which he does,
by most standards), but that he
does a lousy job of telling a story.
His characters don't care. Why
should the reader?
Ellis perhaps realizes what he
is doing: Sean and Lauren attend
a party at her poetry teacher's
house, where they meet Stump
("Used to be Carcass but changed it"), and have an interesting
discussion on writing. Stump is a
poet who has learned his art from
Black Flag and he is writing a
series about bestiality. "I'm
working on the dog section now
where this guy ties a dog up and
is having intercourse with it
because He thinks dog is God. D.G-0-D. God spelled
O-G
backwards. Get it? See?"
Another artist asks whether this
"post-Vietman, post-Watergate,
post- . . . hell, post-everything"
writing is worthwhile, or just
"bogus."
Were Ellis to apply his not inconsiderable stylistic skill to a
worthwhile story, he would begin
to live up to the gushing he has
inspired. Rules of Attraction,
however, is deserving of not even
faint and fading praise.

and serious consequences of
basking your body with rays.

encouraging— 500,000 cases of
nonmelanoma skin cancer will
probably be diagnosed this year,
according to the Skin Cancer
Foundation. Further, skin cancer
is not to be taken lightly either,
as so many Americans seem to be

doing. There will be 2000 deaths
this year due to untreated
nonmelanoma skin cancers, a
number which does not account
for cases in which overexposure
to the sun has caused serious
tissue damage, or caused irretrievable loss of eye or brain
function.

Try now, pay later...'

that the problem seems to be getting worse, with the rising

and the continued idealization of
"California culture" which
idolizes fun-in-the-sun activities.

Compiled from local dermatologists and medical agency literature.
Here's a summary of do's and don'ts
to follow when out there pursuing the
ultimate tan or even just being outside
on a bright day:
**I()apply sunscreen when you expect
to be in the sun for any extended period
of time. The beach, ski slopes,
lakesides, etc.. are all areas where
sunscreens should be used.

**DO apply moisturizers to your skin
if you do burn. There will still be skin
damage, hut it is a little less painful if
you apply lotion to the burn. Those with
aloe-vera are particularly recommended, whereas cold creams are generally
not.
**DO wear sunglasses in the sun and
make sure they are able to filter out UV
rays. These rays damage your retinas
and lead to all sorts of eye disorders.

College-age men and women
to be the worst abusers of
the sun, ritualizing annual treks
to Florida and often participating
in campus tanning as well.
Hopkins, with its studious image,
is not immune from the call of the
rays either. The "Beach — in front
of MSE has had over 100 people
on many a sunny weekend.
Suntanning is, medically speaking, an absorption of ultraviolet
rays from sunlight or artificially
induced light that causes the skin
cells in our bodies to produce
melanin, a dark pigment which
causes our skin to tan. Too much
of that sun will dehydratt- the skin
and kill the cells in the skin's
outer layer.
We are all exposed to the sun
to some extent. and a fair amount
of sunlight is undoubtedly
healthy, contributing items such
as vitamin D for our body's use.
The concern, however, is that
people generally do not know
their limits and overexpose
themselves. That doesn't just
mean burning, however. Even if
you never burn, you may be
receiving too much ultraviolet
radiation and so may suffer later
from some of the diseases
associated with too much radiation, cancers being the most
serious.
There is no. cause for alarm,
sun-seekers, but there is a list of
precautions which dermatologists
and the Skin Cancer Foundation
recommend following
to
minimize your risk (see box).
Most physicians agree that
reasonable adherence to these
seem-

measures will ensure healthy skin
for most of one's life and prevent
the dreaded diseases and
premature wrinkling that have
been seen in increasing numbers.
Many outdoors types have
overlooked these safe and simple
rules, unfortunately, and dermatologists have seen the average
age of skin cancer nose dive from
the 60's to the 30's. President
Reagan is an example of a
Southern Californian with skin
cancer problems, but many doctors have claimed that some
Californians have had to deal with
the skin-salvaging procedures
such as surgery at half the President's age.
There is another controversy in
the tanning picture these days,
and it revolves around the popular
use of tanning salons. Nationally
popular, and doing quite well in
the Baltimore area as well, these
salons have become increasingly
frequented by tanners, particularly in the off season. Lynn'
Kowalski, manager of the Offthe-Beach Tanning Spa, a
Baltimore area tanning salon,
reports that tanning "is a thriving business. We get all kinds of
people, men and women who are
looking to keep up their tan or get
ready with a base tan before they
vacation." Tanning sessions,
which take place in a booth,
where the tanner relaxes for a
short amount of time under UV
lights, provide many people with
the delightful result of a yearround tan.
Cautious about the proliferaton
of the tanning salons is Dr. Paul

Strickland, assistant professor of
environmental health science at
the Johns Hopkins School of
Public Health. His concerns are
that many of the tanning salons do
not provide adequate protection
and information to their.
customers. Furthermore, most
tanning salons only use lamps
which produce UV-A light,
unlike the sun, which produces.
UV-A and UV-If. Strickland feels
that many people who get their
tans at salons unwittingly expose
themselves to long hours in the
sun, thinking that their base tans
will protect theni, when in reality they will not. Strickland would
like to see more regulation of
these spas.
For all the concerns of Dr.
Strickland, however, Ms.
Kowalski points to a pleased
clientele and has few people who
burn or experience bad aftereffects. In addition, Off-theBeach provides goggles for its
patrons and sets tanning times to
prevent overexposure of zealous
tanners.
Tanners are here to stay, admit
most dermatologists, and it's very
hard to fight a trend that all the
beautiful people seem to be doing. Their hope, however, is that
most people will at least be aware
of the danger and take at least
minimal precautions to save their
skin. As the American Cancer
Society tries to warn sunners,
"Fry Now, Pay Later."

Patrick and Benjamin Binder,
a pair of West German Siamese
twins that came to Hopkins
Hospital this month in order to be
separated are recuperating well,
according to spokespersons at the
Hospital. The twins, connected at
the back of their heads, were
separated in a grueling 22-hour
operation on September 5 and 6.
A team of over 70 physicians,
nurses, and health care personnel
attended the operation.
The twins are in a "critical but
stable condition" as this paper
goes to press. .Hospital
spokespersons report that the
twins are being slowly weaned
from their drug-induced coma.
Doctors have kept the twins in an
artificial state of coma with barbituates since the operation last
week in order to promote healing.
The prognosis for the 7 month
old twins seems good—breathing_

has returned to normal and their
arms and legs seem to be functioning well. The twins were
placed on their stomachs early
this week in order to allow the
wounds in their heads to heal
quickly. "It's the first time the
twins have probably been lying
on their stomachs ever," the
Hospital has noted.
The Binder operation was a
unique opportunity for the
Hopkins staff, the first Siamese
separation the Hospital has performed in five years. Doctors used hypothermia and a heart/lung
bypass machine in order to drain
the blood vessels and inactivate
the heart and circulatory systems
for about an hour. This allowed
physicians to separate the major
sinus vein (located near the brain)
that the twins shared. The vein
was separated without incident
and new vessels were constructed
for each twin from tissue from
their hearts. The twins had fully
separated and normally functioning brains.
The twins were in the operating

room last Friday again, but this
time fOr a routine cleansing of
their wounds in order to prevent
the risk of infection. The twohour operation performed on each
twin was primarily so surgeons
could — irrigate and cleanse their
wounds," a routine precautionary
measure for major post-operative
procedure. The twins were
reported to have responded well
to the additional surgery.
The next step for the twins is
to place permanent customdesigned titanium-mesh caps over
the openings doctors have cut in
the infants' skulls. The procedure
has been delayed so far because
Benjamin has been having a little
problem with brain swelling and
the doctors want to allow him
some more convalescent time.
Pediatricians at the Hospital
believe the Binder twins will
grow up to be normal, healthy
adults, but it is still early ib the
game and no one can know for
sure. Doctors will be able to give
a more informed opinion several
months from now.
